A Physicist's Proof of the Central Limit Theorem

Jun 18, 2018

Suppose we are given independent, identically distributed (i.i.d.) random variables . We are interested in the distribution of

Suppose, the probability distribution function (p.d.f.) of is and the p.d.f of is . Then,

\begin{align} \label{master} g(\bar{y}; n) = \mathbb{P}[\bar{Y}=\bar{y}] = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}{dy_1dy_2\ldots dy_{n}\, f(y_1) f(y_2)\ldots f(y_n)\delta\big({\bar{y}-\frac{y_1 + y_2 + \ldots + y_n}{n}\big)}} \end{align}

where is the Dirac delta function defined as:

such that

A Dirac delta exists to be integrated over i.e.

\begin{align} \int_{x’ \in S} {dx\, \delta(x-x’)f(x)} = f(x’) \end{align}

If we were to use this property to integrate in equation \ref{master}, then we would lose one of the integrals, say and lose the symmetry between the terms. To preserve that symmetry, we’ll use another representation of the delta function.

As motivation, consider the Fourier transform of a function : \begin{align} \label{ft} \tilde{f}(k) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\, e^{-ikx}f(x) \end{align}

The inverse Fourier transform is given by: \begin{align} \label{ift} f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{dk}{\sqrt{2\pi}} e^{ikx} \tilde{f}(k) \end{align}

We can plug in the definition of the Fourier transform in equation \ref{ft} into equation \ref{ift} to get:

where \begin{align} \delta(x-x’) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{dk}{2\pi} e^{ik(x-x’)} \end{align}

is exactly the Dirac delta we defined earlier.

We will now use this representation of the delta function in equation \ref{master}. Limits on integrals are from to and won’t be explicitly written.

Effectively, apart from scalings and some normalization terms, this states that the p.d.f of the distribution of the mean is the inverse Fourier transform of the power of the Fourier transform of the individual p.d.f. of the s.

Of course, one can choose explicit functional forms for i.e. the p.d.f. of the s but we want a more general solution. One possible solution is to expand in a series that can then be truncated for large n.

In general, given , we can compute all the moments:

as well as the central moments:

where is the first moment and assumed to be finite. Note that .

On the other hand, suppose we are given all the moments. Can we compute then? The answer to this question is positive as shown below.

Suppose, we are given all moments defined by equation \ref {moments}. We can rewrite those as:

In other words, knowing the moments is equivalent to knowing the derivatives of the Fourier transform of the p.d.f. at .

So, we know the Taylor expansion of :

which can be inverted to give the original p.d.f. . We have used the fact that since is a p.d.f.

We can also do the same expansion using the central moments instead:

In other words, the moments give us the Taylor series terms in the expansion of instead of just before. So,

using .
